I got something to say that might cause you pain
 If I catch you talking to that boy again
 I’m going to let you down
 And leave you flat
 Because I told you before
 Oh, you can’t do that

This wouldn’t be the last time that John Lennon wrote a song about jealousy.

The following year saw the release of Rubber Soul, which featured Lennon’s “Run For Your Life” – in which the threats of abuse to an unfaithful girlfriend gets even more dramatic.

Later, on his 1971 solo release Imagine, the track “Jealous Guy” featured the same sort of topic, although with much more self-conscious lyrics.

Everybody’s green
 ’Cause I’m the one who won your love
 But if they’d seen
 You talking that way
 They’d laugh in my face

This line is quite representative of John’s vulnerability in relationships. It begins with John gloating over his possession of this particular female, because of her everyone else is envious (green).

However, he suspects she is playing him for a fool, and that others may also suspect the same thing, which in turn becomes a source of humiliation.

This song was heavily inspired by some of the R&B music John listened to:

That’s me doing Wilson Pickett. You know, a cowbell going four in the bar, and the chord going chatoong!

Wilson must have acknowledged that he inspired the Beatles because he later on covered “Hey Jude”

This was actually the first guitar solo John Lennon plays on a Beatles album! He shreds too.

I’d find it a drag to play rhythm all the time, so I always work myself out something interesting to play. The best example I can think of is like I did on You Can’t Do That. There really isn’t a lead guitarist and a rhythm guitarist on that, because I feel the rhythm guitarist role sounds too thin for records. Anyway it drove me potty to play chunk-chunk rhythm all the time. I never play anything as lead guitarist that George couldn’t do better. But I like playing lead sometimes, so I do it.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=krC2QWHzXz0

(John Lennon guitar solo starts at 2:04)

I think I’ll let you down (Let you down)
 And leave you flat (Going to let you down and leave you flat)
 Because I told you before
 Oh, you can’t do that

There are many people who think that Bob Dylan drew upon this song for inspiration when writing “Most Likely You Go Your Way And I’ll Go Mine”

And I’m going to let you pass
Yes, and I’ll go last
Then time will tell just who fell
And who’s been left behind
When you go your way and I go mine

So please listen to me if you want to stay mine
 I can’t help my feelings, I go out of my mind

By this point, John is growing increasingly desperate. He is obviously very in love with this girl, and is no longer threatening but pleading her to stay with him and to stop her activities with other men. This time he try’s to tell her he is not in control of his actions, rather he is driven by some kind of jealous neurosis, which is understandable considering some other songs like: “I’ll Cry Instead” and “Run For Your Life”
